Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Quantifying the Downstream Effects of COVID-19 Online Health Information on Risk Perceptions, Decision Making, Policy Preferences, and Preventive Health Behaviors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: The 2019 novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic is potentially the most harmful global infectious disease outbreak in more than a century, and is accompanied by severe economic, social, and political disruptions. The rapid progression of the pandemic has been matched with an “infodemic” of false or misleading online health information about COVID-19 that has been difficult to combat. Although scholars have examined the veracity of online information, susceptibility to false or misleading online information, and its influence on beliefs, there remains a great deal to learn about the infodemic’s downstream consequences. Widely shared falsehoods are likely to affect decision making, attitudes, and behavior, especially over an extended period and outside of the laboratory. This lack of basic knowledge hampers our ability to quantify potential harms of false or misleading online information on public health, and to identify factors and interventions that mitigate its harmful influence. Unprecedented uncertainty, anxiety, and fear about the pandemic, the enormous amount of health information about COVID-19 available online, and a lack of understanding about the long-term impacts of false or misleading information create a pressing need for an examination of how online information influences Americans’ risk perceptions and decision making about the pandemic. <br/><br/>The overarching argument is for a reinforcing spiral over time in which exposure to, and endorsement of, false or misleading online health information about COVID-19 amplifies pre-existing cultural divides in COVID-19 risk perceptions, policy preferences, and behaviors. Previous research has examined how cultural worldviews and online information relates to beliefs, emotions, and behaviors in infectious disease outbreaks, but that research has not done so over an extended period, and it has not focused on the role of false or misleading health information. This project closes this scientific gap by integrating psychological and communication theories of risk, belief change, and decision making to measure the influence of false or misleading online health information exposure on risk perceptions and behavior over a time period. The research involves an innovative integration of social engagement data (e.g., likes, shares on social media), content analysis, survey research, online experiments, and web-tracking data collected over a 7 month study period. <br/><br/>In the COVID-19 context, this project presents a rare and important opportunity to assess the impacts of online information about an evolving health crisis as it unfolds, rather than retrospectively, while generating new scientific insights about processes by which false or misleading online information can harm individuals and society. Furthermore, the COVID-19 pandemic may last for some time, and future novel virus outbreaks are likely. As a result, the problem of false or misleading online health information and its impact on public health drives the need for more effective evidence-based mitigation practices by industry, government, and community actors. This project generates essential guidance, offering best practices for effective risk communication, strengthening resistance to false and misleading online information, and reducing cultural divides that hamper decision making in the context of risk. The project also produces a rich set of data that is publicly available, and results are shared through peer-reviewed journal articles detailing major findings and implications for risk communication practice. Coordinated by the Center for Communication and Public Policy at Northwestern University, the insights and results generated by this project are disseminated to the public through media interviews, university publicity, essays on media platforms such as The Conversation and the Washington Post, white papers, and community talks.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project tracked a survey panel of 1200 Americans between December 2020 and June 2021 to understand what psychological factors, beliefs, and social influences impacted their attitudes and behaviors associated with COVID-19 pandemic. This period was a critical time for the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States as the first COVID vaccines became available and an aggressive vaccination campaign was launched while at the same time a great deal of accurate and inaccurate information about the COVID-19 pandemic, vaccination, and government policies circulated online. How people responded to this information environment during this period was a central focus of the study.

The project surveyed participants each month and knowingly allowed researchers to track their online media behaviors to see what online information sources they consumed daily. Most previous research examining how online content influences people?s attitudes and behaviors relied on self-reported media use rather than tracking actual online behaviors.  In addition, previous studies often collected data from people only at one time point, rather collecting data from the same people over multiple time points to see how their attitudes or behaviors may change. Therefore, the project design provided the opportunity to generate deeper insights on how people?s attitudes and behaviors may evolve over time in response to changes in the information environment about COVID-19 and/or what media and websites they visited.

The project outcomes included scientific contributions and benefits for American society. Scientific contributions include published research showing that that the intention of Black individuals to be vaccinated was initially comparable to that of White individuals in early 2021 but increased more rapidly over time, driven by beliefs about the COVID-19 vaccine. Vaccination rates continued to be lower among Black individuals than White individuals, but the study results suggested this gap was more likely due to factors such as differences in vaccine access for Black individuals rather than hesitancy about the vaccine. Beyond its scientific merits, these findings inform public health policy on addressing individual and structural barriers to vaccination, especially for historically marginalized populations.

The study also employed social media analytics and human content coding to identify 119 accurate and false/misleading claims from highly engaged (likes, shares, comments) news stories and posts shared on social media during the study period. The analysis indicated accurate claims focused primary on COVID-19 vaccination and the risks from COVID-19. False or misleading claims, on the other hand, primarily focused on promoting distrust of public health authorities or policymakers, with about 20% of false/misleading claims centered on vaccination.

Pairing these findings with data from the survey panel, we found that people?s belief in COVID-19 misinformation was associated with less trust in public health authorities, increased risky social behaviors, reduced frequency of facemask wearing, and reductions in the perceived safety and efficacy of COVID-19 vaccination. Conversely, people?s belief in accurate information was associated with greater support for social distancing policies. Frequency of social media use was associated with greater trust in public health authorities rather than less. These findings inform our understanding of how online content impacts the ability of public health actors and policies to mitigate a disease pandemic and promote vaccination.

In sum, the project generated scientific evidence for designing more effective risk communication, strengthening societal resistance to false and misleading online information, and reducing cultural divides that hamper risk and decision-making. Project personnel conducted multiple public presentations with a diverse range of societal stakeholders during and after the study period to ensure project insights were widely distributed. Project personnel also frequently made themselves available to the news media to be an informational resource for the general public about the COVID-19 pandemic. Deidentified social media, survey, and web-tracking datasets will eventually be publicly released for scientific use.
